Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Cells must take up nutrients, communicate with the external environment, and quickly adapt to changes in environmental conditions. To carry out these tasks, the composition of the cell surface (the plasma membrane) is continually adjusted. Through the process of exocytosis, the cell delivers newly synthesized molecules to the plasma membrane or the extracellular space. By the opposite process called endocytosis cells internalize surface components. For example, cells utilize endocytosis to take up nutrients, such as iron, vitamins, and lipids bound by receptors embedded in the plasma membrane. Once inside the cell, the nutrients are released from the receptors and used in various biosynthetic processes. During endocytosis, a portion of the plasma membrane is pulled into the inside of the cell forming a small, spherical structure known as an endocytic vesicle. Various cellular components are in charge of: (1) selecting which receptors and other membrane proteins will be internalized; (2) bending the membrane to generate the incipient endocytic vesicle; and (3) providing the force to pull the vesicle into the cell. Fundamental cellular components known as adaptor proteins, clathrin, and the actin cytoskeleton mediate the three steps of endocytic vesicle formation. This laboratory is studying the molecular mechanisms by which adaptor proteins, clathrin and the actin cytoskeleton carry out the endocytic process. Specifically, this project focuses on how the three steps are mechanistically and temporally coordinated. These cellular components and the endocytic process they mediate are conserved in all eukaryotic cells and are essential for life. The research is carried out using yeast cells, a superb model system amenable to a wide range of experimental strategies.

Broader Impacts
The project will have broad impacts in several ways:
(i) This project will contribute to increase diversity in science and education. This project will support: an under-represented minority PhD student, an outstanding female Research Assistant Professor from an under-represented group, and undergraduate students from a largely minority serving institution who will participate in summer research experiences (REU program) in the laboratory. The project will also support a minority Assistant Professor actively involved in the Colorado Alliance for Graduate Education and the Professoriate, a program seeking to increase the number of minority students historically under-represented in obtaining graduate degrees in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM disciplines).
(ii) The graduate and undergraduate students who conduct the studies will be trained in widely used techniques, critical thinking, and presentation skills through writing reports and manuscripts, giving departmental seminars, and attending scientific conferences.
(iii) Both undergraduate and graduate students in this project will be involved in taking endocytosis studies and fluorescence microscopy into middle school classrooms. This outreach activity is initiated in a bilingual English/Spanish middle school program attended by numerous under-represented minority children. The students will observe different parts of the cell with a fluorescence microscope and perform experiments designed to teach them basic cell biology concepts and spark their interest in science.
(iv) Results from this project will be published in scientific journals, and presented at both specialized conferences and national cell biology meetings, thus impacting the broader scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

The project addressed the fundamental question of how cells transport molecules and material into the cell by endocytosis, a process essential for life. For example, endocytosis mediates nutrient internalization and communication between cells. Particularly, the project focused on the main endocytic pathway, which is conserved in all eukaryotic cells and it is mediated by clathrin, actin and other cellular proteins. In this process a small portion of the cell membrane bends towards the cell interior until pinching off as a small vesicular compartment. Endocytosis proceeds in a tightly regulated manner but little is known about how this regulation is achieved. We used the powerful Baker’s yeast system to advance knowledge and understanding of endocytosis regulation.

 

1) Clathrin works to shape the vesicle membrane by forming a polyhedral lattice around the vesicle but cannot interact directly with the membrane lipids or integral membrane proteins. Our results showed how clathrin is recruited to the plasma membrane by physical interactions with other components of the endocytosis machinery. We also discovered a new clathrin binding mechanism.

 

2) The actin protein interacts with itself to form linear polymers known as actin filaments. Actin polymerization into filaments generates force to bend the cell membrane inwards during endocytosis. We answered one of the major questions in the field: why does actin polymerization occur significantly after the actin polymerization machinery is recruited to endocytic sites? We discovered a mechanism that first inhibits the actin polymerization machinery and then activates it during late stages of endocytosis. The investigation demonstrated that failure to properly regulate the timing of actin polymerization results in deficient endocytosis of surface molecules. The project also uncovered a novel actin binding sequence, which given the multiple functions and binding partners that actin has in the cell will have implications for cellular processes beyond endocytosis.  

 

3) Using an innovative screening approach, we identified previously unknown components and regulators of the endocytosis machinery. These results opened up new directions to understand how endocytosis works. We discovered functions in endocytosis for novel members of two protein families previously known to work on other cellular processes (dynein light chain and ubiquitin regulatory proteins). Thus, the project established new functions for conserved proteins families and revealed novel mechanistic links between endocytosis and other cellular processes.    

 

Broader impacts

This project contributed to support diversity in science and education. It supported training and graduation of the first Hispanic Ph.D. student from our department, Daniel Feliciano. He received the best poster award from the American Society for Cell Biology (ASCB) Minority Affairs Committee, an American Heart Association (AHA) pre-doctoral fellowship, and university level awards. During his last year in the lab (2014), Daniel participated in the famous Marine Biological Laboratory Physiology course at Woods Hole. His excellent training and potential were noted by the course instructors, several of whom offered Daniel postdoctoral positions in their respective labs. He decided to join the lab of Dr. Jennifer Lippincott-Schwartz (NIH), a world leader in organelle biology, and started in November 2014. Daniel is a terrific example of what a mentor aims for in the development of a graduate student.
